Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A. Localized data policy. Documentation in the comments.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Localized data policy controls the flow of data traffic into and out of interfaces and interface queues on a vEdge router. This type of data
policy is provisioned locally, on the vEdge router, using access lists. It allows you to classify traffic and map different classes to different
queues. It also allows you to mirror traffic and to police the rate at which data traffic is transmitted and received.
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/config-18-4.pdf

comments.content:
Data policy influences the flow of data traffic traversing the network based either on fields in the IP header of packets or the router interface on which the traffic is being transmitted or received. Data traffic travels over the IPsec connections between vEdge routers, shown in purple in the adjacent figure.
Control policy, which is similar to standard routing policy, operates on routes and routing information in the control plane of the overlay network. Centralized control policy, which is provisioned on the vSmart controller, is the Viptela technique for customizing network-wide routing decisions that determine or influence routing paths through the overlay network. Local control policy, which is provisioned on a vEdge router, allows customization of routing decisions made by BGP and OSPF on site-local branch or enterprise networks.

discussion.content: A is correct

discussion.content:
It is important to understand “configuration for WAN Edge routers“ 

That means you choose the answer for two router VPN 0. The answer is B because VPN 0 interface ge 0/1 ip address 172.16.15.5/24 is the configuration for WAN edge-2 and vpn 0 ip route 0.0.0.0/0 172.16.13.1 is to configure default route in vpn 0 of WAN edge-1.

The question can be misleading but when utilizing networking basics of logical addressing scheme and hierarchy, the main configuration takes place on the primary devices first 
(or WAN Egde-1) then to other devices.

The default route is clearly via WAN Edge-1 due to the 172.16.13.0/24 Class B subnet

answer is C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge-20-x/policies-book/service-chaining.html

The SD-WAN book literally teaches that ‘set’ and ‘service’ are on 2 separate lines. Therefore, ‘A’ is the correct answer. Based on the 2021 book. Although, you can find online where ‘C’ is also referenced. Typical Cisco ambiguity.

A is also correct. set and service commands don't need to be in the same line.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/data-policies.html

IMO answer is C. This is a snippet of an example config:
policy
 lists 
 site-list firewall-sites
 site-id 1
 control-policy firewall-service
 sequence 10
 match route
 site-id 2
 action accept
 set service FW vpn 10
 default-action accept
apply-policy
 site-list firewall-sites control-policy firewall-service out

So answers A and D are not correct, as in the syntax an extra "set" is used.
Answer B is incorrect bc it does not include the vpn and service name FW in the command.

Answer -A 
Question says --> W2 loopback received via OMP to the OSPF neighbor on the service-side VPN, so here service side VPNS come into 1-511. 
Option -A 
1.) has mentioned with VPN 10
2.) Loopback set with /32
3.) After default action accept there wont be any set commands. In option A it says ACTION ACCEPT

comments.content: Yes, and even if set commands were allowed in the default action, putting the set commands there would not limit them to that loopback as needed.

discussion.content:
key differences are the VPN number and that the loopback address is a /24 or /32.

I think it should be VPN 10 and /32, which would make A correct.

I concur with the network group.
Loopback addresses are /32 normally when setting up peer to peer interfaces.

VPN 0 is a transport WAN service , so option B and C are not correct
VPN 10 - is within the range of service VPN's (besides 512 and 0 which are dedicated management and transport exclusive VPN services)

Set commands are no longer accepted to the interface once the default-action command is imitated!

Option A is the only answer that accommodates the request.

The answer is A:

EXPLANATION

if we see the link:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/control-policies.html

DETAIL 01 LOOPBACK = /32 and not /24
DETAIL 02 in answer D
 A) it says "default action" and not "default-action" = misspelled command
 B) even if it was good, the metric attributes are applied in the default option and not in the sequence 1

Detail 03: Question says: Which configuration fulfills these requirements? (ALTERNATIVE A is the most correct)


if we see the link:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/control-policies.html
the structure is:

Structural Components for Localized Control Policy

Answer is A
There is no possibility to SET something within the Default-Action configuration mode.

Structural Components for Localized Control Policy
policy
 lists
 as-path-list list-name
 as-path path-list
 community-list list-name
 community [aa:nn | internet | local-as | no-advertise | no-export]
 ext-community-list list-name
 community [rt (aa:nn | ip-address) | soo (aa:nn | ip-address)]
 prefix-list list-name
 ip-prefix prefix/length
 route-policy policy-name
 sequence number
 match
 match-parameters
 action
 reject
 accept
 set parameters
 default-action
 (accept | reject)
 vpn vpn-id router bgp local-as-number neighbor address
 address-family ipv4-unicast
 route-policy policy-name (in | out)
 vpn vpn-id router ospf
 route-policy policy-name in
 redistribute (bgp | connected | nat | omp | static) route-policy policy-name
